title: Norovirus warning as vomiting bug outbreaks hit school and hospital wards

Public health experts are sounding the alarm over norovirus following a number of outbreaks of the nasty winter vomiting bug.

Medics are seeing more cases as the weather turns cold and they have warned Britons to take precautions so they don't get struck down by unpleasant symptoms.

About 700 people have come down with the highly contagious virus in the past 12 weeks.

Last month, a school in Lancashire was forced to close for a deep clean after dozens of pupils and staff were taken ill in a suspected outbreak.

Several hospitals closed wards or cut visiting hours and asked people who were feeling unwell to stay away after patients suffered vomiting and diarrhoea.

(Image: PA)

Outbreaks are more common at this time of year.

These are some of the places where confirmed or suspected outbreaks have been reported.

Lancashire

Carnforth North Road Primary School was shut after 50 pupils and staff were taken ill in a suspected norovirus outbreak, LancsLive reported.

The school underwent a deep clean before reopening days later.

Five staff members and 45 pupils experienced symptoms.

(Image: iStockphoto)

Staffordshire

Last week, a ward at Cannock Chase Hospital was forced to restrict visiting hours to just an hour a day due to an outbreak, StokeonTrent Live reported.

Visitors were told to stay away if they had experienced symptoms or been around someone with norovirus symptoms in the previous three days.

Matt Reid, head of infection prevention at the Royal Wolverhampton Trust, said: "We have had an outbreak of norovirus on Fairoak (ward)."

Warwickshire

Similar visitor restrictions were imposed at George Eliot Hospital in Nuneaton for four days until they were lifted last week.

Patients on three wards were struck down by diarrhoea and vomiting, CoventryLive reported.

A hospital spokesperson said: "Please help us to protect our patients and staff by not visiting the hospital if you are feeling unwell - especially if you have diarrhoea and vomiting or flu symptoms."

(Image: Getty Images/iStockphoto)

East Yorkshire

Doctors have told patients that norovirus is currently "doing the rounds" in Hull and East Yorkshire, HullLive reported.

Paula South, of the NHS East Riding of Yorkshire CCG, said: "We would strongly urge anyone who thinks they may be infected to stay at home, so not to risk spreading the virus further."

People in need of medical advice should call NHS 111 rather than visiting a GP, she added.

Almost 700 cases

Public Health England said there have been 696 laboratory reports of norovirus in England and Wales since early August.

That figure is slightly lower than the average of 703 for the same period in the previous five seasons (2014/15 to 2018/19).

Eight outbreaks of suspected norovirus occurred at hospitals in England in September, down from the average of 13.

(Image: Getty Images/Science Photo Library RF)

Six led to a ward/bay closure or restrictions to admissions and three were confirmed as norovirus.

Data for October is not yet available.

As for the upcoming winter months, Public Health England said: "It is not possible to predict how the current season will progress."

Norovirus is known as the winter vomiting bug, but cases can occur at any time of the year.

The main symptoms are nausea, diarrhoea and vomiting, but people could also experience a fever, headaches or sore arms and leg.

The symptoms usually appear suddenly within a day or two of infection and people normally feel better within a day or two.

Health experts urge people to treat themselves at home and stay off school or work until the symptoms have stopped for two days.

The best way to stop the spread of the virus is frequent hand washing with soap and water.

Norovirus spreads very easily through close contact with someone who has the bug, touching surfaces or objects that have the virus on them and then putting your hands in your mouth, and eating food prepared or handled by someone who has the virus.
